title: salmonids
text: text to see if the page updates when rendered

Our project is advancing three research areas to create a new sustainable aquaculture feed toolbox


1) Mapping the environmental footprint of aquafeeds










Raw materials used in aquafeeds are sourced from fisheries and agriculture systems globally. Geographical differences in how raw materials are produced and processed can drive substantial changes to the environmental footprint of aquafeeds.
By mapping the cumulative pressures associated with different feed scenarios - we can provide detailed information on how various ingredient combinations used by our partners could optimise the carbon, water, nutrient, and biodiversity footprints of aquafeeds.





2) Predictive modelling of local ecosystem impacts



Aquafeeds are harvested globally but used locally. While the raw materials and ingredients in aquafeeds have changed dramatically in recent years, there is limited information on how changes to feed composition affects ecosystem processes, structure, and biodiversity at local scales.
We are developing and testing a range of ecological models as predictive tools, using detailed data from aquaculture digestibility and growth experiments to provide new approaches to aquafeed sustainablility assessment.












3) Future scenario projections to assess trade-offs across sustainable development goals






Aquaculture’s growth in future relies on the supply of different marine and terrestrial feed resources and a suitable environment to grow target species. Like other food sectors, supply faces numerous risks such as climate and global change.
We are examining how short-term shocks and long-term climate risks alter the resilience and sustainability of aquafeed supply, and how supply risks be minimised through different feed formulation scenarios.

section: New tools to support environmentally sustainable aquafeeds
text:
New tools to support environmentally sustainable aquafeeds
Our project aims to develop a new interdisciplinary sustainability assessment framework to improve our understanding of the consequences of changing aquafeeds in aquaculture.

Why are aquafeeds important?
Aquaculture currently produces over half of all fish consumed by humans and is an important sector for future food security. Over 70% of animal aquaculture is dependent on human-made ‘aquafeeds’ which can account for the majority of environmental impacts in the life-cycle of farmed fish. Aquafeeds thus present a key lever for improving the sustainability of the aquaculture sector.

section: New tools to support environmentally sustainable aquaculture feeds
text:
New tools to support environmentally sustainable aquaculture feeds
Our project aims to develop a new interdisciplinary sustainability assessment framework to improve our understanding of the consequences of changing raw materials used in aquaculture feeds.

What are aquafeeds made from?











Aquafeeds are manufactured using a large range of ingredients and raw materials, from crop, fish and livestock products and byproducts, to insects and single-celled organisms. Feed composition has changed dramatically in recent years and continues to evolve as resource availabilty changes. Yet, comprehensive understanding of the environmental implications of feed composition changes is lacking.
We are working towards a more holistic understanding of environmental pressures (greenhouse gas emissions, water extraction, nutrient pollution, habitat disturbance) from feed production and how these translate to impacts (e.g. biodiversity, ecosystem function) at local and global scales.

section: New tools to optimise feeds in support of ecosystem-based aquaculture
text: New tools to optimise feeds in support of ecosystem-based aquaculture

title: Sustainable Aquafeeds Project at AMSA 2023
text: Project co-lead Rich Cottrell and PhD Candidate Sowdamini Sesha Prasad attended the Australian Marine Science Association conference in the Gold Coat in July ‘23. Sowdamini presented her geometric stoichiometry modelling framework for understanding how changing raw materials and ingredients in aquafeeds can result in shifts in the nature of waste in and around fish farms. Rich presented work in preparation on how raw material origins can be as important as feed composition for the environmental footprint of aquaculture feeds, and co-led a session on ’The Future of Sustainable Seafood in Australia’

title: Sustainable Aquafeeds in Singapore!
text: At the end of our first full year of the Sustainable Aquafeeds Project, PhD Candidate Sowdamini Sesha Prasad and Research Fellow Rich Cottrell travelled to Singapore in December 2022 to present their research on local to global aquafeeds sustainability assessment at the World Aquaculture Society conference. Great science, networking, and fun had by all (with the exception of bizarre student mixer!) - and Sowdamini’s first international conference presentation. Well done, Sowdamini!

title: Annual workshop 2022
text: We had a very successful three-day workshop in Nov 2022 with our industry partner, BioMar visiting us from Norway!

title: Sustainable aquafeeds project at WAS Darwin 2023
text: CI Dr Louise Adams and PhD student Xin Zhan (Kathy) attended the World Aquaculture Society conference held in Darwin this year!
